awd_titl_txt: Cultivating Scientific Literacy and Action through Place-based Experiential Learning: Expanding the Use of a Campus Farm as an Interdisciplinary Learning Hub
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest in undergraduate STEM education by studying how place-based experiential learning (PBEL) can enhance undergraduate student learning about science.  PBEL is an instructional strategy that connects student learning to a local context.  It also provides students with opportunities to identify, define, and solve real problems. The nation's ability to solve the complex problems it faces and to maintain national prosperity require educating both students who enter the STEM workforce and students who pursue non-STEM careers. Consequently, this project will serve both STEM majors and non-majors.  Although the number of campus farms has increased 13-fold since 1992, they remain an underused resource for undergraduate education.  This project aims to use campus farms as a local context for authentic, interdisciplinary STEM learning. To achieve this goal, the project will develop and implement campus farm-based PBEL modules that integrate STEM disciplines and non-STEM disciplines such as business and communication.  Students will have opportunities to apply multiple types of knowledge and inquiry strategies within their PBEL course work.  Such learning experiences have been shown to increase student and instructor enthusiasm, enjoyment, engagement, content knowledge, critical thinking, and civic mindedness. Results of this project have the potential to make STEM accessible to more students, to educate the future workforce about how to successfully participate in interdisciplinary collaborations, and to enhance perceptions about STEM's role in society.

The Center for Urban Ecology and Sustainability at Butler University will leverage Butler's campus farm as a place of inquiry, discourse, and community engagement.  The project will pursue two goals: 1) to develop and implement a collection cross-disciplinary PBEL course modules for both STEM major and non-major courses; and 2) to measure project efficacy in achieving outcomes including student learning (e.g., environmental science literacy; scientific reasoning; place attachment and meaning; civic mindedness), faculty collaboration, and institutional sustainability. To achieve these goals, the Center's previously-developed PBEL framework will be refined and used to guide a faculty-staff learning community.  This learning community will facilitate the effective design and implementation of farm-situated PBEL modules in STEM and non-STEM courses. Researchers from the Purdue School of Engineering and Technology and the STEM Education Innovation and Research Institute of Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis will quantify and qualitatively examine PBEL implementation fidelity, identify best practices to improve curricular implementation, and determine impacts on targeted student outcomes. Long-term, the project expects to scale its approach to other undergraduate institutions that have campus-based farms, and to expand the curriculum to include ethics. The project activities have the potential to be modified for use in multiple formal and informal educational settings.  This project is a Development and Implementation project (Engaged Student Learning track) that is supported by the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) Program: Education and Human Resources (EHR).  The IUSE : EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all undergraduate students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the Program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising educational tools and practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
National prosperity and the solving of complex social challenges require educating two siloed populations of STEM learners: 1) those striving to “assimilate into the subculture of science” in preparation for the STEM workforce and 2) those pursuing a career in the non-STEM workforce, but with a need to understand “the subculture of science and how it operates” to civically and professionally engage in solving societal challenges. The overall goal of the project was to develop and implement place-based experiential learning (PBEL) modules in four STEM courses in five non-STEM courses, all of which situated student learning within local urban farms, such as Butler University’s campus farm or another local farming operation. Urban farms were treated as places of academic inquiry, discourse, interdisciplinarity, and community engagement. Upon module implementation, mixed method data were collected and analyzed to measure program efficacy in enhancing student environmental science literacy, place attachment, sustainability meaning making, and civic mindedness.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in the streamlined expansion of campus farm curricular connections beyond agriculture and sustainability disciplines and into other STEM and non-STEM disciplines under a common PBEL pedagogical framework. This framework creates a “cycle of innovation” between research and practice to understand how STEM content can be effectively taught and integrated into any course and how focusing on a central theme or socio-ecological problem across the undergraduate curriculum positively impacts student learning, faculty collaboration, and the solving of key social problems. The PBEL approach resulted in significant pre/post module increases (p < 0.001) for all courses (n = 167) in student civic mindedness (CMG), environmental science literacy (ESL), place attachment, scientific reasoning, and situated sustainability meaning making (SSMM). Effect sizes (Cohen’s d) for these measures ranged from small (scientific reasoning = 0.27) to large (CMG = 1.173). Embedding small doses of environmental science content into non-STEM courses increased environmental science literacy in non-STEM majors (pre/post module ESL: n = 208, p < 0.001), whereas embedding PBEL and critical reflection in STEM courses increased civic mindedness in STEM majors (pre/post module CMG: n = 87, p < 0.001). 

Cultivating the educational environments in which such outcomes could be realized required faculty development. A two-semester curriculum for a faculty learning community (FLC) was created and implemented to ensure PBEL consistency, fidelity, and competency across participating courses. All FLC participants (n=9) designed and implemented PBEL modules in their courses. While the sample was small (n=8), faculty surveys revealed statistically significant change in faculty civic self-efficacy scores (p < .001) with a large effect size (3.296).

Through pedagogical collaboration, cross-disciplinary faculty challenged their students to tackle broad socio-environmental problems from a range of disciplinary perspectives to solve complex problems. This not only developed faculty capacity for research and scholarly activity, but it also generated knowledge of, and advocacy for, sustainability by students and faculty that shifted institutional perspectives on and investments in sustainability. Thus, the program serves as a model for resource-limited PUIs and larger universities to capitalize on existing infrastructure to achieve large-scale improvements in undergraduate STEM education while increasing faculty collaboration and institutional support for sustainability.  

More profoundly, by teaching science content and scientific reasoning to a population of non-STEM learners through the lens of inquiry in their own disciplines, the program established a pedagogical model that helps to address a core challenge from the NSF INCLUDES program “How can students who are not successful or not interested in STEM continue to engage with science in their careers and personal lives?” For example, through this curriculum, a student majoring in critical communications and media studies not only learned best practices and techniques in their field but also learned to communicate complex science topics to the public and to apply learnings to their personal lives through consumer responsibility and civic engagement. The merging of inquiry, science content, and discipline-specific material within both a real-world community-engaged location and a student’s chosen discipline (whether STEM or non-STEM) can transform student perspectives of science arguably in ways that once-off, required science courses cannot. As this project has shown, pedagogical approaches like PBEL can increase students’ valuing of scientific inquiry, scientific content knowledge, personal civics, and the public purposes of their own professional disciplines. The PBEL program trains future STEM and non-STEM professionals to collaborate and apply STEM and other discipline-specific knowledges, as well as critical thinking skills, to address the challenges of today’s world and improve all sectors of the workforce.
